title: Dun & Bradstreet Report on AT&T
historical_context: This article provides a financial overview of AT&T during a period of significant corporate restructuring following antitrust actions in the early 1980s.
target_audience: Security professionals, financial analysts, corporate researchers, and hackers interested in telecommunications history.
short_summary: The article presents a detailed financial report on AT&T, including key financial metrics, ratios, and historical context regarding its corporate structure and operations following antitrust regulations.
summary: In this article, Elric of Imrryr delivers a comprehensive financial report on American Telephone and Telegraph (AT&T) as of December 31, 1986. The report includes critical financial data such as total assets, liabilities, net worth, and various financial ratios that provide insights into the company's operational efficiency and profitability. The figures reveal a company undergoing significant changes, particularly in the wake of the antitrust actions that led to its divestiture in 1984, which reshaped its corporate structure and market strategy. The report highlights AT&T's substantial sales figures and employee count, underscoring its status as a major player in the telecommunications industry at the time.
summary_details: The financial records presented in the article detail AT&T's performance metrics, including cash flow, accounts receivable, and inventory levels, alongside industry comparisons. The report also discusses the implications of AT&T's restructuring, which was mandated by the U.S. Department of Justice, leading to the formation of regional holding companies. This restructuring aimed to enhance competition in the telecommunications market. The article serves as a historical document, capturing a pivotal moment in corporate telecommunications history and providing valuable insights for those studying the evolution of corporate governance and market dynamics in the tech industry.
